Message.Title: The New Economy
Message.Msg: Here's what I see happening in the US economy. The recovery will NOT be consumer based, nor will it be driven by housing. The recovery will be driven by manufacturing, initially based on supplying the current energy boom, then based on industries that will expand and come to this country to take advantage of energy that is cheaper than the rest of the world. Unfortunately, manufacturing employment will not be a major beneficiary as the new manufacturing plants and processes will be capital intensive, not labor intensive, so higher unemployment and stagnant wages will be with us for awhile. However, as the retirement of baby boomers gains momentum, this will have a big impact on the employment picture as the pool to replace aging baby boomers is smaller than the number of boomers retiring. All of this will, of course, take years to play out, but the economy emerging today is NOT the same economy as it was when the financial crisis began.

Topic.Title: More about the settlement hearing.

Message.Msg: I have no doubt there are issues that need to be resolved, and the banks must be held accountable in accordance with applicable laws, regulations, and the provisions of the settlement agreement. However, everyone keeps forgetting the primary issue that keeps the banks from being able to set up standardized processes and that issue is that most of the mortgage and foreclosure rules are state based, meaning there are 50 states and each has different rules on how things should be done. We all know banks need to do a better job, but we also need to remember what it is that they have to deal with. Seems to me that one of the best solutions is to come up with national standards that would apply to every state, not state by state rules that many times overlap and conflict with each other.

Let's get this resolved, sooner rather than later.

Topic.Title: BAC $8.5 billion Settlement

Message.Msg: To put Countrywide into bankruptcy is a trump card for BAC, the worst scenario. This is why many companies are agreed to BAC $8.5 bil settlement, if BAC put Countrywide to bankruptcy, they will get nothing. The thing is, I have a feeling BAC will not put Countrywide into bankruptcy. If the Judge dissaproves the settlement, then this will lead the lawsuit to dragged to another few more years or more. The ramification of the fail lawsuit will definitely send BAC down to at least $11 or least. Likewise, if the judge approves BAC settlement, we can see a considerable uptrend in BAC as well. Nothing will really happen between now until BAC 8.5 bilion lawsuit, which definitely wont happen this month and i dont see in July either. Another significant milestone can affect the BAC share price will be next month, July Quarterly report. The forecast is 25 cent per earning per share. Any above 25 cent earning per share will give a big boost to BAC share price, which I think its very possible. They already had a meeting before the last quarterly report on how to boost BAC income between Monihyan and other BAC Managers.

Topic.Title: The New Economy

Message.Msg: While the consumer will remain an important part of the economy, I just don't see them driving the recovery as they have in the past. It's going to take some time for people to regain what they lost in household wealth during the collapse of housing prices. I also believe they will avoid the massive amounts of debt of the past. The one thing that could have a major impact either way is the student loan debt. That debt load alone will prevent much extra consumption post graduation.

Message.Title: *DRAM $4.1 UP AGAIN…TO $30++, WHY?: 1) MEMORY PRICES UP EXPONENTIALLY, 2) HUGE RECENT MEMORY/SOFTWARE DEAL WITH AMD, 3) $8M CAP, 4) 1.4 SHARE FLOAT
Message.Msg: Dataram (NASDAQ: DRAM) with $8M market cap is poised for a huge break out– I am talking double, triple, quadruple, etc. from today’s $4/share price. The rapidly improving fundamentals easily support $35, the price it achieved several times before (the last time in 2010), but DRAM is now significantly stronger and having explosive earnings potential for its only 1.7 million outstanding shares (1.4 million share float). Two main reasons for these assertions - they are easy to corroborate by any serious value investor: 1……..Memory prices have almost doubled this year and were 70% higher in the quarter to be reported soon vs. the previous quarter. Traditionally, the memory business was it’s main business having been a pioneer and a respected company since 1967. DRAM prices continue to literally explode during the current quarter and are expected to continue to go up into 2015 due to manufacturing shortages and high demand. 2……..AMD and DRAM recently announced in May (5/8/2013 AMD and 5/12/2013 DRAM) that they have agreed on a memory manufacturing partnership. This partnership includes Dataram Corporation as an AMD memory-manufacturing partner to produce AMD's new Gamer Series memory. Gamer Series memory is compatible with AMD and Intel platforms, supporting both AMP and XMP memory profiles. "AMD Radeon RG2133 Gamer Series Memory is armed with features designed to outperform the competition on any task," said Roman Kyrychynskyi, product director, Graphics Business Unit, AMD. "Designed with multi-platform compatibility in mind, the AMD Radeon RG2133 brings cutting-edge technology, as well as uncompromising quality and compatibility for PC gamers. "AMD and Dataram have worked together to significantly enhance the dynamic background load-and-save feature in order to create a seamless, non-volatile RAMDisk experience," said Jason Caulkins, CTO, Dataram. "This underscores AMD and Dataram's continued dedication to delivering the highest-performing memory products

Topic.Title: The New Economy

Message.Msg: I don't disgree that investment will give an added boost to GDP this time around but even muted consumption is necessary for growth. Over $3 trillion as been added to household wealth since 2009 and the employment rolls are growing so consumption as a % of the economy should remain above 71%. Finally, if your thesis is correct and if you buy off on Say's law that supply creates it's own demand, the economic recovery should pick up momentum down the road. This assumes that the Obama administration and Congress don't screw up things even more.

Topic.Title: Remember in 2008 when G W Bush had Hank Paulson bailing out all the GOP donor banks with trillions of your tax dollars !

Message.Msg: Actually, as far as the banks go, TARP was a highly successful investment for tax payers. Earnings to the Treasury exceeded $43 billion against losses of $5 billion. Most all has been repaid and there are still about 230 loans out. If you actually had read the development of TARP, in mid Sept, after Lehman went belly up, it was Paulson, Bernanke, Geithner and Lockhart, realizing a financial meltdown was imminent met with Bush with the rec to fund the big banks with capital, and TARP was born. If there had been a systemic collapse of the financial system there would have been a depression with 50 million thrown out of work by the '30's depression standards. Bush said go. He didn't form a committee to study it or, or test the political waters with his advisors or get on his podium in front of his teleprompter and jawbone the thing to death. One of Bush's better decisions.

Topic.Title: BAC Settlement Hearing Decision

Message.Msg: I'm going to let the judicial process work before I come to any conclusions about these latest allegations revealed this evening. However, if they prove to be true I will have to admit that it could be the last straw for me as well. The idea that alleged activities such as bonuses for mortgages, removing documents from files, and deliberately changing system records seems to be completely arrogant and stupid in times like these. But, as I said, I'm waiting to see how this plays out before I make up my mind.

Topic.Title: BAC Settlement Hearing Decision

Message.Msg: It is unlikely that Judge Kapnick would undermine the authority of the Trustee in the State of NY by overriding the negotiated settlement unless there was a clear conflict of interest at hand. Apparently, in the State of NY the Trustee’s authority in negotiation has never been overridden by a judge before and this can set a bad precedence.
